CatDescriptText: Mr. Morris Kaufman, news dealer, East Liberty and Mr. Samuel Yimin, self-employed, Uptown, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, February 17, 1962, pg. A3 with question: "Do you think Bible reading in public schools is constitutional or unconstitutional?" Mr. Morris Kaufman's answer reads: "According to the recent ruling it is unconstitutional, but I can't say for sure because I'm not well versed in the matter.  I can't say whether it's right or wrong."  Mr. Samuel Yimin's answer reads: "I think it's all right because if the people don't have religion, they will go out and murder and do other crimes.  This way, with Bible reading, there is a fear of the law."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Morris Kaufman wearing dark corduroy cap and dark plaid coat, standing near Brass Rail Restaurant, Smithfield Street, Downtown; Portrait of Samuel Yimin wearing light colored tweed jacket with small lapel pin, standing in front of C.C. Mellor's, Smithfield Street, Downtown
